Posts.Content: Pinkfuzzysocks34 wrote: My mom was diagnosed a week ago (to the hour ) with stage III invasive ductal carcinoma breast cancer. The tumor is too large to operate on (i.e., a mastectomy is the only option). When she did her biopsy, one lymph node was taken and it was found to have cancer. More will be removed during the mastectomy to see if they are cancerous. If four or more are cancerous, chemotherapy will be needed. I understand the process, I just want to know the chances. What are teh chances that all are affected? Did you have lymph node involvement? How many were cancerous?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Did you have lymph node involvement? Some questions? Pinkfuzzysocks34 edwards750

Posts.Content: Pinkfuzzysocks34 wrote: I'm sorry if this is a touchy topic for some, I really am. My mom was recently diagnosed with stage 3. The first thing I did was look up survival rates on this site. There are some listed for stage 3, some for stage 4, etc. The ones that were stage 3- does that mean that the cancer hadn't spread to other body parts (thus becoming a stage 4)? I don't understand how someone couldn't survive breast cancer unless it became a stage 4 first. God bless you all,  you're so helpful :)  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How do they figure survival rates =/ Pinkfuzzysocks34 Pinkfuzzysocks34

Posts.Content: Pinkfuzzysocks34 wrote: My mom was diagnosed about a week ago with Stage III invasive breast cancer. She went to the doctors and the doctor she saw was very conservative about her having to have chemotherapy. The cancer is in her lymph nodes, but they're going to do more testing to see if it's anywhere else. Still a chance, I'm just concerned. Should we get a second opinion?  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Stage III but they say no chemo? Good news, but is it accurate? Pinkfuzzysocks34 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Pinkfuzzysocks34 wrote: First of all, I'm seventeen, so I'm not young enough to be shielded from what's going on. My mom was just diagnosed today with breast cancer. They caught it early (she decided to have a mammogram after nine years of not having one). I'm just scared, ya know? She really had problems telling my sister and I. Fortunately, my mom and I have a very honest relationship and we agreed to always be there for each other.  The MRI is on Wednesday. What should I/she expect (I'm not going)? Since they caught it early, what are her chances of survival?  I'm still kind of in a shock. I haven't cried or showed any emotion. I guess I'm still just in a daze... but to me it doesn't seem that bad. They caught it early, they know what they're doing, and they already have a plan of what to do. Ideas?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My mom was just diagnosed? Help! Pinkfuzzysocks34 ebann
